Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Improving the identification of Japanese individuals in forensic contexts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subsequent to deaths resulting from natural disasters, armed conflicts, and homicides, the identification of decedents is paramount and depends on the accuracy of the scientific methods employed in the biological profile (sex, age, ancestry, and stature of skeletonized remains). However, most biological profile methods were developed in North America on individuals of African and European descent, and it is unlikely that such methods can generate accurate biological profiles for Asian individuals. Moreover, Native Americans historically served as biological proxies for Asians due to their shared genetic history, resulting in the largely untested assumption that Native Americans and Asians share nonmetric skeletal features. The continued reliance on methods developed from non-Asian populations is especially problematic in forensic contexts where Asian remains are likely to be recovered (i.e., large U.S. cities and international humanitarian settings). This project will statistically test and refine the nonmetric methods used in sex and ancestry assessment for adults in the Chiba University skeletal collection, curated by Dr. Yoshiharu Mastuno, which represents one of the few documented anatomical collections in Asia. The proposed research will contribute to the development of more quantifiable and replicable methods necessary to increase the accuracy of biological profiles and identifications for an understudied East Asian population.

As sex is reliably determined from the presence or shape of traits on the skull, clavicle, humerus, and pelvis, these traits will be assessed and assigned an ordinal score based on their robust or gracile expression. The scores and documented sexes will be analyzed statistically to identify the traits that best indicate male or female, and to compare the sexual dimorphism observed in Japanese individuals to North American populations. Additionally, nonmetric cranial traits commonly used to identify Native Americans will be assigned an ordinal scored to test the hypothesis that Japanese individuals differ from Native Americans in their trait expressions and frequencies. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The efficacy of the biological profile (sex, age, ancestry, and stature of skeletonized remains) in forensic anthropology depends on the development, validation, and refinement of population-specific methods. However, most biological profile methods were developed in North America on individuals of African and European descent, and it is unclear whether such methods can generate accurate biological profiles for contemporary Asian individuals. Additionally, Native Americans historically served as biological proxies for Asians due to their shared genetic history, resulting in the assumption that Native Americans and Asians are homogeneous and share metric and nonmetric skeletal traits, despite significant differences in population histories. The continued reliance on methods developed from non-Asian populations is especially problematic in forensic contexts where Asian remains are likely to be recovered. The current study statistically tests and refines the methods used to visually assess nonmetric sex from cranial and postcranial remains, and establishes nonmetric cranial trait frequencies that be used in ancestry estimation from documented anatomical collections in Japan. This project contributes to a larger study by the PI in the form a doctoral dissertation that examines the sexually dimorphic and cranial trait differences between two geographically and genetically disparate Asian populations (Japanese and Thai), thereby examining intergroup skeletal variation within Asia.

Nonmetric data collection occurred at Chiba University, the primary host institution, and Jikei University's School of Medicine. The skeletal remains of over 400 individuals of known sex and age who lived during the late 19th to early 20th century were analyzed. To investigate sexual dimorphism, 15 bony features on the cranium, mandible, clavicle, humerus, and pelvis were assigned ordinal scores based on their female-like or male-like expressions. To establish cranial trait frequencies, over 30 bony features of the cranium and mandible commonly used in forensic ancestry assessment were assigned ordinal scores. Additionally, several individuals from the Chiba University skeletal collection were re-analyzed in order to explore the effect of intra-observer error in the scoring of nonmetric traits. The intact skulls in the Chiba University skeletal collection were digitally photographed in eight views in order to document the diagnostic cranial trait expressions. Univariate and multivariate statistical analyses will determine which sexually dimorphic traits best predict sex, and which cranial traits represent Japanese individuals. The results will be compared to other Asian and non-Asian populations for a dissertation in the Department of Anthropology at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. The project's refined sex assessment methods and established cranial trait frequencies for Japanese individuals will serve as a foundation for the ongoing testing and refinement of Asian-specific biological profile methods needed to increase the accuracy of identifications within this large and varied group. Further, any statistically significant morphological differences found between Japanese and non-Japanese groups may enable anthropologists to more accurately differentiate and identify East Asian-derived skeletal remains from commingled, mass fatality assemblages.
